Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching aim of this project is to expand the structural theory of permutation classes, to unify the disparate strands coming together in this theory, and to test the power of the emerging viewpoint and toolbox by bringing them to bear on problems of exact enumeration and the characterization of growth rates.

Historically, the study of permutation classes arose from two independent streams in 1960s and 1970s. One was combinatorial in nature, and concentrated on the enumeration problems for permutations with a small set (size 1 or 2, typically) of short (length up to 4) forbidden patterns. The other was coming from Theoretical Computer Science, and was concerned with sets arising from common sorting mechanisms and their combinations. In the past 10 years or so these two strands have come much closer together, and this interaction has created a new, fast developing area of combinatorics, with significant interactions with Theoretical Computer Science, the Theory of Computability and Complexity, Algebra, and Computational Biology, to name only a few. Apart from the continued interest in sorting mechanisms and enumeration problems, major new strands of research have emerged including the structural theory of classes, the asymptotic behavior of classes, generalized pattern avoidance, packing densities, algorithmic and decidability problems, and geometrical methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Historically, the study of permutation classes arose from two independent streams in 1960s and 1970s. One was combinatorial in nature, and concentrated on the enumeration problems for permutations with a small set (size 1 or 2, typically) of short (length up to 4) forbidden patterns. The other was coming from Theoretical Computer Science, and was concerned with sets arising from common sorting mechanisms and their combinations. In the past 10 years or so these two strands have come much closer together, and this interaction has created a new, fast developing area of combinatorics, with significant interactions with Theoretical Computer Science, the Theory of Computability and Complexity, Algebra, and Computational Biology, to name only a few. Apart from the continued interest in sorting mechanisms and enumeration problems, major new strands of research have emerged including the structural theory of classes, the asymptotic behavior of classes, generalized pattern avoidance, packing densities, algorithmic and decidability problems, and geometrical methods.

The overarching aim of this project was to expand the structural theory of permutation classes, to unify the disparate strands coming together in this theory, and to test the power of the emerging viewpoint and toolbox by bringing them to bear on problems of exact enumeration and the characterization of growth rates.

One of the most important goals of the project was to extend the PI's characterization of growth rates of permutation classes from the point where uncountably many permutation classes appear to where uncountably many growth rates occur. This aim was completely accomplished in two preprints (one joint with the Pantone) resulting from the project. Another significant aim was to investigate the enumerative and structural properties of infinite grid classes. Two significant advances in this direction were made. First, in joint work between the PI, Albert, Brignall, and Ruskuc, a long-standing conjecture of Albert and Atkinson was established via the coupling of infinite grid classes and formal language theory. Second, joint work between the PI, Albert, and Pantone established a framework for the evaluation of growth rates of infinite grid classes which led to new derivations of several results of Bona. The project also initiated the study of strongly rational and strongly algebra permutation classes, which is the basis of ongoing research.
